I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment of up to $30,000,000 in the India Agri Business Fund II (Fund II), not to exceed 20% 
of Fund II’s total capital commitments and not resulting in the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
being the single largest investor in Fund II.  
 
II.  THE FUND 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
2.  Description. Fund II, to be established as a company incorporated in Mauritius, will be a 
closed-end private equity fund (PEF), formed to invest in agribusiness companies in India and 
having a target capitalization of $200 million. Fund II is a follow-on fund to India Agri Business 
Fund I (Fund I), which raised $120 million in 2008, and invested in similar medium-scale private 
sector agribusiness enterprises. Fund II will be managed by Rabo Equity Management Company 
Ltd.  (REMCO,  fund  manager),  also  a  company  incorporated  in  Mauritius,  affiliated  with 
Coöperatieve Centrale Raiffeisen-Boerenleenbank B.A. (Rabobank, sponsor), a prominent global 
agriculture focused bank. Rabobank is the key sponsor of Fund II (and of Fund I) and the majority 
shareholder of REMCO. REMCO will engage Rabo Equity Advisors Private Limited, (REAL, fund 
adviser), a company incorporated in India, as its advisor, to provide investment advisory and 
management services. 
 
3.  Investment identification. ADB has been exploring opportunities to support specific 
segments  of  the  agriculture  sector.  ADB’s  private  sector  operations  have  used  various 
instruments and investment vehicles to allocate capital and resources to the agriculture sector: (i) 
since 2006, about $100 million has been allocated to the sector through credit lines to banks; (ii) 
the Trade Finance Program has supported about $1.4 billion of food and agriculture trade 
transactions since 2006; (iii) direct loans and equity investments—ADB has approved four direct 
loans for agribusiness companies, aggregating to $108 million, from August 2012 to August 2013; 
and (iv) investment in sector-neutral PEFs, which further invested in agribusiness-focused private 
enterprises.1 
 
4.  While there is continuing scope for direct financing, the dedicated, sector-specific PEF 
route to support agribusiness offers several benefits, such as (i) having a focused market and 
country coverage for a large and diversified market like India, and reach to highly specialized 
investments; (ii) supplementing the financial intervention with a more pronounced element of 
technical and managerial support, which will be provided by a sector-specialist fund manager; (iii) 
countering the cyclicality and uncertainty of the sector, through a portfolio approach toward 
agribusiness investments; and (iv) partnering with other private and multilateral institutions and 
aggregating a higher level of capital, through a leveraging effect. 2 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
5.  The agriculture sector faces severe challenges relating to (i) diminishing yields from 
farmlands; (ii) limitations in expanding irrigation and increasing the net sown area; (iii) rapidly

reducing groundwater resources and ever-increasing dependence on farm inputs (principally 
fertilizers) to maintain farm-output levels; (iv) the high level of farm-level and storage wastage 
caused by poor linkages to markets and distorted pricing policies; and (v) limited value addition, 
which constrains rural income and employment levels, encouraging migration to potentially worse 
living conditions in urban slums, and widening regional imbalances. 3 
 
6.  In this context, Fund II will create a transmission mechanism to bring improved technology 
(like drought-resistant seeds), advanced resource conservation techniques (like micro irrigation), 
reduced wastage (through agri-infrastructure facilities like granaries and warehouses), and higher 
value addition (through primary processing activity in the dairy, fruit and vegetable, and oilseeds 
industry,) to the farm level. The fund manager’s contribution to the business, technology, and 
financial aspects of the investee companies—in addition to the new capital—is expected to 
improve governance and profitability at the company level, and deliver improved inputs, services, 
and value to the agribusiness sector at the farm level.4 
 
7.  Fund II will leverage both (i) the sponsor’s agribusiness expert knowledge relating to the 
global agricultural value chain, which is well demonstrated through the extensive research, 
advisory, and commercial banking services of Rabobank in emerging markets, including India; 
and  (ii)  the  fund  manager’s  dedicated  resources  and  preferential  access  to  commercial 
agribusiness opportunities in India, through its India-focused private equity investment strategy, 
which has been well demonstrated in the investment selection for Fund I. As such, Fund II, being 
a  follow-on  fund,  will  benefit  significantly  from  the  pipeline,  business  linkages  relating  to 
origination, structuring, and funding of new investments and transaction-related cost efficiencies 
emanating from Fund I. 
 
8.  Strategy. The fund manager’s investment approach is based on four central principles: 
achieving attractive entry valuations through proprietary sourcing of deal flow; (ii) proactive risk 
management of the risks associated with execution and expansion; (iii) enhancing value creation 
by advising portfolio companies on their business strategies and operations; and (iv) proactive 
exit planning, including installing back-stop arrangements in all investment structures. Fund II’s 
overall investment objective is to generate returns driven by earnings growth and by providing 
expansion  capital,  through  a  significant  minority  (or  majority  in  exceptional  cases)  equity 
investment in established agribusiness companies, led by experienced management teams; and 
to grow these, within 3–5 years, to a size that would be of interest to strategic investors, primarily 
larger domestic or global private sector players in those segments. 
 
9.  Fund II will pursue an investment strategy similar to that of Fund I, making investments of 
$12 million–$15 million each, in a balanced and diversified portfolio of 10–12 established, high-
growth businesses. The fund manager will focus on companies in the agribusiness sector 
servicing domestic demand and with possible export potential that are poised to benefit from 
growth  trends  in  the  following  four  subsectors:  (i)  agri  inputs  and  farm  services,  (ii)  agri- 
infrastructure, (iii) primary processing, and (iv) processed food products and services. The 
financial analysis details the Fund I investees, the strategic and operational changes brought 
about by the fund manager, and their impact on the investees’ performance. It also provides a 
summary overview of the revenue and earnings of the portfolio companies in Fund I, after

C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
 
1.  Ownership 
 
10.  Fund II will issue share capital to its investors, including the sponsor and investment 
manager. Fund II’s initial close is set to raise a total of $80 million, from Rabobank ($30 million), 
CDC Group PLC ($30 million), and Development Bank of the Netherlands (FMO) ($10 million), 
alongside ADB’s proposed initial investment of $10 million. After its first close, Fund II will 
approach a wider base of private sector institutional investors, to progress toward its target size 
of $200 million.6 
 
11.  Mauritius has been categorized as ”Largely Compliant” with internationally agreed tax 
standards, in the latest progress report prepared by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation 
and  Development’s  Global  Forum  on  Transparency  and  Exchange  of  Information  for  Tax 
Purposes.7 Fund II  will  obtain  a tax residency certificate  issued  by the  Mauritius  revenue 
authorities, and its investments are expected to benefit from Indo–Mauritius treaty arrangements 
for the avoidance of double taxation, in line with the structure for Fund I. 
 
12.  ADB’s review of Fund II does not give ADB cause to believe that it has been established 
or is being used for cross-border tax evasion, money laundering, or terrorism financing in the 
jurisdictions involved in the investment.

making  processes.  Fund  I’s  investment  team,  under  REAL,  which  will  also  take  on  the 
responsibilities as Fund II is operationalized, is comprised of 13 investment professionals (to be

18.  For Fund I, all the employees of REAL also co-invested 0.35% of the total capital  amount 
committed by Fund I, in each of the portfolio companies. This threshold will be raised to 1.00% 
for Fund II. This is normally not seen with other PEFs in Asia, and is a very positive factor for 
bringing in greater alignment of interests between Fund II’s investors and the fund manager’s 
team. It also acts as a source of the team’s long-term commitment. 
 
3.  Governance Structure 
 
19.  The fund manager will follow a rigorous multi-staged, deal evaluation process before a 
transaction is selected for final investment. In the initial stages, deals are logged in and mapped 
to the pipeline of agribusiness investments in India, assessed by the REAL team, and a rapid 
assessment of the profile of the sponsor and the investment, in terms of risks and feasibility, is 
done. The database of more than 640 private sector Indian agribusiness transactions assessed 
by the team since 2008, is a critical reference for scanning and assessing new opportunities. 
Deals considered potential opportunities for investment are selected for initial due diligence and, 
within this subset, a few are proposed to Fund II’s investment committee for initial approvals. 
 
20.  The investment committee for Fund II will follow a two-stage process. The transactions 
selected  at  the  first  stage  are  subject  to  extensive  due  diligence—financial,  business  and 
operations,  technical,  legal,  accounting  and  forensic  background  checks,  as  well  as  the 
environment,  and  health  and  safety  dimensions  of  the  investment.  Only  a  select  few  are 
considered  acceptable  and  processed  for  final  decisions  by  the  second-stage  investment 
committee. 
 
21.  The data relating to the investment process for Fund I underscore its rigor and the quality 
of investment selection. Of nearly 640 transactions included in the deal flow, only 10% were 
selected for initial due diligence, of which only 25% went on to the detailed due diligence stage, 
and  eventually  Fund I  invested  in 10  of these  640  deals  (a  1.50%  deal  conclusion  level, 
highlighting a very high level of selectivity). 
 
22.  Fund II will also establish an advisory committee consisting of a minimum of five members, 
selected from among the larger shareholders (limited partner equivalents), including ADB, should 
it invest in Fund II. The role of the advisory committee will be to advise Fund II’s board of directors 
on (i) review of valuation of Fund II’s assets, (ii) any proposed deviation in the investment 
objectives and policies of Fund II, (iii) resolution of any conflicts of interest, (iv) extension of the 
investment period and term of Fund II, and (v) provide such advice as   Fund II’s board may 
request.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
25.  ADB will provide an equity investment of up to $30,000,000 in Fund II, not to exceed 20% 
of Fund II’s total committed capital, and not resulting in ADB being the largest investor in Fund II. 
To mitigate risks, ADB will initially invest $10 million in the first closing of Fund II, with the balance 
of up to $20 million to be invested in Fund II’s second or final close—provided certain targets 
relating to Fund I exits and returns, and final Fund II size, are met within the stipulated period. 
 
B.  Financial Analysis of Expected Returns and Assumptions

C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Exit Strategy 
 
27.  Fund II’s preferred exit strategy, as seen in Fund I, is through trade sales, and, to a 
significantly lesser extent, public listings. In the fund manager’s view, many multinationals and 
domestic conglomerates look to acquire companies in high-growth sectors where they do not 
have a presence, and will pay a premium for agribusiness companies that have a leading industry 
position,  geographic  coverage,  strong  corporate  governance  and  accounting  standards, 
operational efficiencies, and stable professional management. The fund manager works toward 
creating  these  value-enhancing  propositions  and  then  aims  to  deploy  its  local  and  global 
relationships, principally through Rabobank, toward this end. Most of the investments in Fund I 
have built-in put option provisions as last-resort exit arrangements. Fund II is expected to follow 
a similar approach. 
 
2.  Reporting Arrangements 
  
28.  Fund II will provide to ADB quarterly unaudited and audited annual reports including 
financial statements, a fund overview, and an overview of the portfolio, with information on each 
portfolio company’s performance and valuation, which ADB will review and follow up on as 
appropriate. 
 
29.  ADB will be represented on Fund II’s advisory committee, which advises Fund II on 
matters such as conflicts of interest and other issues related to fund governance.11 Detailed due 
diligence has highlighted that Fund I reporting arrangements and disclosure standards match 
expectations.  Fund  II  will  adopt  similar,  and  some  improved,  reporting  standards  and 
arrangements. 
 
 
11  The role of the advisory committee is to represent the interests of Fund II’s investors. It will not participate in Fund 
II’s investment process or make investment decisions.

6 
 
D.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
30.  ADB’s participation in the first closing, as the nodal Asia-focused development financing 
institution (the other existing investors Rabobank, CDC Group PLC, and FMO have also invested 
in Fund I), is expected to have a positive signaling effect on other potential participants, and is 
expected to facilitate capital mobilization for Fund II. By linking its first-close commitment to exits 
and evidence of the commercial performance of Fund I, ADB is indirectly increasing the prospects 
for expedited capital raising, as this record will bolster the confidence of second- round private 
sector investors, who will place higher emphasis on commercial returns. This approach draws 
significantly from the lessons learnt from ADB’s previous PEF investments. 
 
31.  ADB will also establish better standards and measurement frameworks for capturing the 
development- and safeguards-related aspects of Fund II’s performance as its capital is deployed. 
These measures will help in more meaningful and causal reporting of Fund II’s development 
impact, which has been an occasional drawback of such interventions and has been highlighted 
in the detailed evaluation reports on PEF performance prepared by ADB.

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACTS AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs  
 
1.  Impacts 
 
38.  Fund II will contribute to two development impacts. The first is establishment of additional 
private  equity  funds  that  have  a  primary  or  dominant  focus  on  Agribusiness  in  India.  By 
demonstrating financial performance and commercial returns in agribusiness, Fund II will help 
draw more private sector capital in this sector in India. This is a significant positive contribution of 
Fund II, as the agribusiness sector is typically owned and controlled by traditional traders and 
semiprofessional family-owned small businesses. These businesses, though with very strong 
roots  in  operations,  require  support  in  improving  standards  of  professional  management, 
disclosure, and transparency to gain acceptability from external private capital providers (debt

7 
 
 
and equity). PEFs like Fund II can make critical contributions by bringing better management 
practices to these businesses, which also enhance the long-term viability of the sector (footnote 
5). 
 
39.  The second key impact is increased productivity, diversification, and value addition in the 
agriculture sector in India—reflected in higher growth rates, particularly for basic food grains 
critical for food security, and higher value-added produce. Increased equity participation and value 
addition in the agribusiness sector, along with measures to increase productivity, will create 
income and employment opportunities at the farm level; and facilitate balanced, inclusive, and 
sustainable economic development in rural India. 
 
2.  Outcome 
 
40.  Outcome. Fund II will achieve positive development and financial returns. It will create a 
transmission mechanism to bring improved technology (like drought-resistant seeds), advanced 
resource  conservation  techniques  (like  micro-irrigation),  reduced  wastage  (through  agri- 
infrastructure facilities like granaries and warehouses), and higher value addition (through primary 
processing activities in the dairy and oilseeds industries,) to the farm level. 
 
3.  Outputs 
 
41.  The core output of ADB’s investment will be the establishment of Fund II, through the 
capital raised in the first and the subsequent close, and Fund II’s investment in companies with 
business and operations focused primarily on the Indian agribusiness sector. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
1.  Consistency with Midterm Review of Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 
 
42.  The Midterm Review of Strategy 2020 has identified agriculture as one of the areas, for 
linking ADB operations to inclusive growth, and emphasized that continued investments in the 
sector will "create jobs, promote economic opportunities, and reduce vulnerabilities by connecting 
the poor to markets and increasing their access to social services and productive assets".12 This 
has also been validated through independent valuations, which concluded that ADB’s investments 
in this area had generated jobs, raised rural incomes, and reduced poverty.13 
 
43.  The country partnership strategy for India, 2013–201714 identifies agribusiness as one of 
the key sectors to be supported by ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department. 
 
2.  Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 
 
44.  The investment thesis of Fund II overlaps well with ADB’s agriculture sector strategy,15 in 
particular with the expanded partnership with the private sector to attract more direct investments 
in productivity enhancement, agro-processing, agro-retailing, and other non-farm rural business.

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
46.  Potential environmental impacts that may originate from Fund II’s activities may include 
the generation and discharge of hazardous waste, air emissions, wastewater discharges, and 
release of contaminated materials. Other issues could include threats to plant biodiversity, 
susceptibility to pest attacks, occupational health concerns, and safety hazards. These impacts 
are expected to be site- and investment-specific, and will be avoided substantially by adhering to 
well-established and accessible international practices and design and process criteria, which 
Fund II will adopt. All of Fund II’s portfolio companies are expected to be classified category B, 
and Fund II is classified category FI overall in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009). On social safeguards, the investment is classified FI, treated as category C, as any 
investment having involuntary resettlement or indigenous peoples impacts, will be considered 
ineligible for investment. 
 
47.  Fund II and its investees will establish and implement an environmental and social 
management system (ESMS), commensurate with the impacts and risks of their operations. Fund 
II and its investees will comply with all applicable laws and standards on environment, health, and 
safety aspects; and Fund II will not invest in any entity that is engaged in an activity named in 
ADB’s Prohibited Investment Activities List.16 Fund II’s ESMS will include provisions requiring 
Fund II and portfolio companies to comply with national labor laws and to take measures in 
relation to internationally recognized core labor standards, in accordance with ADB’s Social 
Protection Strategy.17 The investment is categorized as having no gender elements. Since this is 
a follow-on fund, and the ESMS for Fund I and its investees have already been implemented, 
there is high certainty that the fund manager will adhere to these requirements for Fund II. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
48.  Fund II, the sponsor, REAL, and REMCO were advised of ADB’s policy of implementing 
best international practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing 
of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions 
prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in 
the event of noncompliance.

D.  Assurances 
 
50.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank, 18  the 
Government of India will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed 
assistance to Fund II. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance 
satisfactory to ADB, following the approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
51.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $30,000,000 in India Agri Business Fund II, from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth 
in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject:
The fund manager will focus on companies in the agribusiness sector servicing domestic demand and with possible export potential that are poised to benefit from growth trends in the following four subsectors: (i) agri inputs and farm services, (ii) agri- infrastructure, (iii) primary processing, and (iv) processed food products and services.


The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated May 2020 is provided for the ADB project 47931-001 in India .
